text:
JACKIE: Today, I
have Kristin Sainani. Kristin Sainani is an
associate professor at the Stanford University.

She teaches statistics
and writing, works on statistical
projects and sports medicine,

and writes about health
science and statistics for a range of audiences. She authored the health column
Body News for Allure magazine

for a decade. She is also the statistical
editor for the journal Physical Medicine &
Rehabilitation, and she

authored the statistics
column, Statistically Speaking, for this journal. She teaches the popular massive
open online course Writing

in the Sciences on Coursera. She was a recipient of
the 2018 Biosciences Award

for Excellence in
Graduate Teaching at Stanford University. So thank you all for being here.

And I will now pass it over to
Kristin for our presentation today.

KRISTIN SAINANI: Thanks Jackie. So yeah today, I'm going
to be talking about how to analyze research data.

And my goal for
today is to allow you to peer under the hood
of a real data analysis.

Unfortunately, I think
many PhD students and applied researchers are
never taught the data analysis

pipeline. They may be taught just a
tiny sliver of data analysis, such as how to run
specific statistical tests,

but there are so much
more to data analysis. And so today, I'm going to walk
you through all of the steps and including my thought
process in those steps.

And I'm going to
use a real example. These are data that I am
actually currently analyzing.

Since these are
unpublished data, I'm just going to share
a subset of the data today so as not to give
away the whole story,

but I'll tell you that what
I am seeing in this subset is pretty similar to what I'm
seeing in the larger data set.

I want to thank the PI of
the study, Dr. Emily Kraus, for allowing me to use
her data in teaching.

So this study is a
cross-sectional survey that was administered online. And today, we're
going to look at data

on 409 competitive
adult female runners. And the study was
interested in a syndrome

called female athlete triad. So this is where athletes
don't intake enough calories

for the amount that they
are expending in exercise. That can lead to energy
deficiency which can in

turn cause women to lose
their menstrual periods and have lowered
levels of estrogen,

do runners with
female athlete triad have an increased prevalence
of depression or anxiety?

The main independent
variable for this study

was something called the female
athlete triad risk score. So this is a
validated risk score

that's actually used to screen
athletes for female athlete triad. And you get points for low
energy availability which

is related to restricted
eating behaviors, for low BMI, for irregular periods,
for late menarche which

is a delayed first period, and
for having a history of bone stress injuries.

The dependent variables
are depression and anxiety. And these were measured by a
validated questionnaire called

the PROMIS questionnaire, which
is actually frequently used in research.

All right. So now, let's talk about the
steps of a data analysis. I've broken it down today
into five main steps.

So you're first going to
process and clean your data to get it ready for analysis. Then you need to spend
time familiarizing yourself

with all of the variables
in your data set. This is going to help
inform step three, which

is when you actually get
to test the main hypothesis in your study. Then you need to
check for robustness.

So what this means
is you're going to make small tweaks
to the analysis and make sure that the whole
thing doesn't fall apart.

If it falls apart,
then it's not robust. And finally, you have
to get everything ready for publication,
which includes

coming up with a story. A set of tables and figures that
tell the story of your data.

And spend some time thinking
about how to put those together so it's a clear story.

And you have to prepare
final code documents.

When I do a data
analysis, I actually spend the majority of my
time in steps one and two.

And they're time consuming. And I would also
argue that these are the most important steps
of any good data analysis.

And this is because if there
are quirks in your data that you are not aware of or if
there are errors in your data,

it doesn't matter how good
your statistical model is. It's a garbage in garbage
out situation then.

And I actually think that
a lot of the errors that I see in the published literature
arise because researchers often

neglect steps one and two. Everybody wants to
rush to step three to testing those
main hypotheses.

But if you don't do due
diligence on your data, that really is a big
source of errors.

Again unfortunately,
I think everybody wants to rush to step three,
and most statistical test areas

or many statistical
courses actually focus almost exclusively
on step three there

on how to do specific
statistical tests, like how to run a T-test
or how to run an ANOVA.

And that might give researchers
the mistaken impression that data analysis is
synonymous with step three

out there when in fact
step three is just a tiny sliver of a well
done data analysis, as we're going to see today.

So what are we're
going to do now is I'm going to walk you through
the steps of a data analysis

using this example
of female athlete triad and mental health. So first thing we're going to do
is process and clean our data.

And there's just a lot of
things involved in this stuff. It does take quite
a bit of time.

And you might
think, oh, this step is going to be really tedious. But I actually really
enjoy cleaning data.

So there's something fun. There's something that's a
little bit of like a miracle

detective work when you're
digging into your data and trying to find
all the things that could've gone wrong. So I find that fun.

And then there's just
something really satisfying about cleaning your data. I think it's kind
of like when you

go into the back of
that closet that you haven't cleaned
for like 10 years, and you pull everything out.

And you kind of wash
down the shelves and throw things out
and organize everything. There's just something
really nice about knowing

that the back of the closet,
even though you can't see it, that it's in order. And I feel the same
way about just knowing

that my data are in order. So the first thing you're
going to do in this step is you're usually getting
data in from somewhere

like Qualtrics or REDCap. What you're going
to do is you're going to immediately
put those data

into a proper statistical
analysis program. Something like R or SAS
where you can write code

to do your data processing and
also your analysis eventually. And I want to make the point
that you really shouldn't

be processing data in Excel. And the reason I
bring this up is that I realized over
the years that there's

a lot of researchers who are
very comfortable in Excel, and so they're tempted to do
a lot of their data processing

in Excel. This is just a bad idea because
it's highly inefficient.

I'll give you an example. I got brought in on a
project a few years ago, and when the data were
entered in REDCap--

there'd been some issue where I
think some of the baseline data points had been entered
in a follow up column,

and so there was an error. The PI of that study had
downloaded the data into Excel

and was going through
observation by observation to realign everything, which
probably took her 30 or 40

hours of work. I was able to download
the data from REDCap and dump it into SAS and
write like four lines of code

and fix the problem
in 20 minutes. So if you're processing
data in Excel, you're probably wasting time.

If you could write some
code to do the same thing, it's going to be
much more efficient. I also don't like Excel
for processing data

because when you're
working in Excel, there is a high chance of
accidentally introducing

errors. And there's no real
record of them, and it's not reproducible. The other thing is when
you update your data,

say in REDCap, if you've
done everything on Excel, you're going to
have to download. And you're going
to have to repeat

all of those manual steps
in Excel, whereas if you've written code, you just port
your data, your new data, back

into SAS or R, and
you rewrite your code. It takes two seconds
to update the data.

So other things we're
going to be doing here is I spend a lot of
time renaming variables. So they come in from Qualtrics
or REDCap with funny names.

And I'm not going to
remember those names, so I'm going to
name them something I can remember and type easily.

I'm also going to be
calculating new values. So in this example data
set, the participants

took a questionnaire
about depression, and it was eight questions long. Those eight questions
get processed

into a single depression score. So I'm going to write
some code to do that. I'm also going to spend a
lot of time rummaging around

in my data checking for errors. And this is time consuming. And I actually
spend a lot of time

actually emailing back and forth
with the PI and the people who are maintaining
the database to see if we can resolve those errors.

Or sometimes,
they're not errors. They're just weird data
points, and we have to decide how to score those.

We're also going to worry about
how to handle missing data. And I'm going to figure out
if any observations need

to be excluded.  All right. Just for fun, what
I'm showing you here

is the data processing
and cleaning code that I have written for this
particular data analysis.

This is SAS code. I do most of my data
processing in SAS actually. As you can see,
it's 12 pages long.

So this is a lot of work,
data processing and cleaning. In contrast, I'm going to show
you a regression model later.

That regression model took
like five lines of code. So a lot of work goes into
data processing and cleaning.

So as I mentioned,
we're going to get data.

Often for research,
data is going to be something
like from Qualtrics. The data for this study
were entered into Qualtrics.

So what I'm showing
you in this screen now is what the spreadsheet
looks like when I download the data from Qualtrics.

And I'm just showing
you the variables for height and weight. So height was entered actually
in two separate columns.

They asked the participants
to record their height as feet and then separately as
the remaining inches.

And then weight was
just asked in one column out as weight in pounds. Notice that the
variable names here are

really awful like Q93_39_TEXT. I'm never going
to remember that.

So I'm going to rename that
variable into something easy like height. I'm going to write
some code that's

going to clean this data up. I'm going to rename the
height variable to height. I'm going to combine those two
columns into a single column.

So if you entered
5 feet 7 inches, I'm just going to calculate
that you're 67 inches tall.

Weight, I'm going to
rename that variable. And then I calculated BMI
from their height and weight.

The height data actually
makes a really good example

to talk about checking,
the need for checking your data for errors. So that variable was asked
in sort of a weird way.

They were asked to answer,
how many feet are you? And then, how many
inches are you? So like you were supposed
to put in 5 feet 4 inches.

But there were a
lot of variations on how that got answered. When I went to calculate
height, what I did

was to take your feet
variable, multiply by 12, and add inches to get
the height in inches.

But that led to some impossible
and weird height values, which I then fished out
of the data set to try to resolve what was going on.

So for example,
some people came out with heights of like
124 and 125 inches. Well, why did that happen?

So actually it turned
out I could figure out some of what went on here. So some people when they
were asked to answer feet,

they put 5 feet. But then when they were
asked for the inches, they didn't put the remaining
inches like 4 inches.

They put their height in total
inches like I'm 64 inches tall. Well obviously when I
went to calculate height,

I came up with this weird value. But this one is resolvable. I know what they meant. They meant that
they're 64 inches tall,

so I can easily fix that. That is not a problem. I'll just change that
to 64 and 65 inches.

Another thing people did is when
they were asked their height, they put in for the feet a
decimal place like five--

I'm 5.44 feet tall. And then they didn't
enter anything for inches. So when I went to calculate
height, I got a missing value.

But this one is also
resolvable, right? I know what they meant. I'm just going to take the
5.44 and multiply by 12,

and I am able to fill in
for example, that 5.44 feet corresponds to 65 inches.

No problem. Now, there were some
heights that in the end I couldn't resolve.

They just had weird values. So somebody entered
8 feet 8 inches. Maybe they meant
5 feet 8 inches,

but I can't really tell. Somebody entered
2 feet 4 inches. I don't know what that means. So these heights actually
can't be calculated,

which means I'm not
going to be able to get a BMI for this person. So I'm just going to leave
those data as missing,

and these people will
be missing a BMI. Just a fun story
though, the magic

of crowdsourcing
on Twitter here. Last week, I posted on Twitter
about this upcoming webinar.

And I shared this
particular slide, and an observant researcher
out there, Todd Daniels,

tweeted back and said, hey, that
one that says 1 foot 85 inches, maybe they used metric units.

I hadn't thought of that, but
it totally makes sense, right? 1 meter 85 centimeters. That translates to
about 72 or 73 inches.

So we may have resolved
that one data point through the magic Twitter.

All right, another thing we
had to do with these data is the participants took
this PROMIS depression

questionnaire. And this consists of eight
questions about depression. And there are things like
in the past seven days,

how often have you been bothered
by the following symptoms? And it's things like I felt
worthless or I felt sad.

The participants answer this
question on a Likert scale. Rarely, never, sometimes, often.

And those answers
get translated. All eight answers on
those eight questions

get translated into
a single depression score that ranges from 8 to 40.

So I wrote some code
to process those data, and I named the new variable
depnow for current depression.

And we end up with a
score between 8 and 40.

Now for this
particular variable, I did have to think
carefully about missing data.

So you'll notice that some
people didn't fill out any of the questions. These are actually
pretty easy cases,

because they're
just going to get a missing value for depression. In fact, what happened
on this because it

was an online survey is
that some people signed up to take the survey. They got like two or
three questions in

and then they abandoned
the whole thing. They decided maybe it
wasn't worth their time. So we have a bunch of
people who basically

have blanks on everything. Obviously, they're
going to be excluded from the analysis in the end. So those cases are
in some ways easy.

But then I have cases like the
one that you see up here now where this person entered
seven of the eight questions,

but they neglected to
answer question six. So what do I do
with this person? Do I give them a
depression score

or do I treat their
depression score as missing? I did think carefully
about what to do here.

And so to figure
that out, what I did was to do a little
bit more detective work is I went into the
data set and tried

to quantify how often
were people missing items on the depression
questionnaire?

And so I just counted up. How often were people
missing zero items, meaning that they answered
all the questions? How often were they
missing one item?

They just missed one question. How often were they
missing all eight? And fortunately, it turns
out that most of the cases

are pretty easy. Most people either answered
all of the questions or they answered none of them.

So those are easy cases. We only had five
participants who had partial data on the
depression question.

So there were three people
who actually missed one item. There was one person
who missed three items,

and there was one person
who missed four items. So I had to make just
a decision about what to do about these people.

And so it made sense
to me to say, hey, if you're missing
one item, I can just give you the minimum
score on that one item,

and I can still give you a
depression score that's going to be reasonably accurate. But if you were missing
three or four items that

seemed like I wasn't going
to be able to get an accurate depression score, so I'm going
to count those people as having

a missing value for depression. So overall I ended up
with 58 participants

didn't get a depression score. And in this particular
analysis, there were three main variables.

The triad risk score,
the depression score, and the anxiety score. And if you were missing
any one of those,

you really couldn't contribute
much to the analysis and solve for the key variables. So when we started here with 476
people who started the survey,

but when I excluded
people who were missing any one of those
three main variables, we ended up with a final
sample size of 409.

All right, so what are
we going to do next? Now we're going to
get to step two. This is a step where
you familiarize yourself

with all the variables
in your data set. You really have to
dig in to make sure that you understand
all of the variables

and really understand what's
going on in your data. This is really going to help
inform step three, the model

building step. So what are we doing here? Well, one thing I'd
love to do, because I

love to make a bunch of
histograms with my data. I just plot a histogram of
each individual variable

to look at the distribution. And actually funny story, I
teach a 3/4 statistics sequence

at Stanford. So I have many of the same
students all year long. And I've probably been
presenting a lot of histograms

to them all year long. So in this 3/4, we do these
data analysis projects. And so the other day, they had
just gotten a new data set,

and they were working
together in teams, in breakout rooms on Zoom. And I was floating around
the breakout rooms. And my heart was warmed so
much, because immediately

a lot of my students
were immediately drawing histograms of their data. So it's their instinct to
look at the distributions

and histogram, so I felt
like I taught them something. I'm also going to
be, in this step,

calculating
descriptive statistics. I'm going to be really
understanding each variable. And I'm going to be exploring
simple relationships

between the variables. Which variables go together?  So as an example,
here is a histogram

for age in my data set. So what are we looking at? A histogram. On the x-axis, we have
different ranges of age.

On the y-axis, we
have how frequently different ages occur. So for example, I had--

this is roughly about 18 to
just over 20 out of about 10% of my sample in that
18 to 20 bucket.

What turned out to
be interesting here is that I actually have a
pretty wide range of ages.

So I actually have some women
who are in their late 50s, and I have some women who
are actually postmenopausal.

And this turns out to
be really important. I had to email back and forth
with the PI of this study to say, hey, how do we
score postmenopausal women

for menstrual irregularity which
is one of our key variables? Just being aware that
the age range is so wide

also reminds me that I'm
going to need to control for age in my analysis.

This next histogram
that I'm showing you shows the distribution
of the triad risk score. Remember this is my main
independent variable.

So this risk score
ranges from 0 to 10. And 10 means that
you have more traits

of the female athlete triad. I'll just point out that we had
only one person who scored a 9, and only one person scored a 10.

So those really high
scores were actually rare. I'm going to say
a little bit more

about where this
score comes from now.

So the triad risk score
comes from summing up five individual
components that are each

scored on a scale from 0 to 2. So for example, you get points
for menstrual irregularity.

If you have normal
periods, your score is 0. If you have somewhat irregular
periods, you get a score of 1.

And if you're missing
periods altogether, you get a score of 2. You also get points for late
menarche, a late first period.

So if you had your
first period at age 15, you get a score of 1. If it's age 16 or older,
you get a score of 2.

You get points for prior
bone stress injury. So if you've had one stress
reaction or stress fracture,

you get one point. If you've had more than
one, you get two points. You get points for a low BMI.
So under 18.5, that's one point. Under 17.5, that's two points.

And then finally, you get points
for low energy availability. And this is scored
actually in this data set

based on a series of questions
that we asked the participants about their eating behaviors.

And we were really looking for
restrictive eating behaviors that might limit the
amount of calories that somebody was taking in.

I think this low energy
availability risk score actually turned out to
be kind of an important part of the whole story here.

So I'm going to say
just a little bit more about this risk score. So the participants
were actually

asked a pretty long
series of questions about eating behaviors including
a history of eating disorders.

Have they ever been diagnosed
with an eating disorder? And they were asked
if they engaged in certain restrictive
eating behaviors.

And they were asked
how frequently they engaged in those behaviors
and also things like purging. If they had a history
of eating disorders

or frequent restrictive
eating behaviors, those things would give you a
high score on the low energy

availability risk score.  And I'm just showing
you here the histogram

for that variable, the
history of an eating disorder. I think this variable
is kind of interesting and actually an important
part of the story here.

So this is a binary variable. We asked women if
they'd ever had an eating disorder diagnosed.

You got a 1 if you did
and a 0 if you didn't. And I thought what's
interesting here is actually the rate of eating
disorders, or recent history

of eating disorders, is
actually pretty high. It was about 30% of the sample. So that it struck
me as kind of high.

Now to be fair, it was
kind of a broad group of eating disorders. It included subclinical
eating disorders

like disordered eating. So we may have seen
a high rate just because it was kind of a broad
definition of eating disorder.

But it also does make
me worry a little bit that we're going to have
to worry about selection

bias in this data set, right? The people who filled out this
questionnaire might have been--

people who have
these issues might have been more likely to
fill out the questionnaire, because they were
interested in these issues.

So that's something
we're going to tuck on the back of our minds.

All right, the main
dependent variable here is this depression score. This is the PROMIS
depression score,

and I'm showing you
the histogram here. It ranges from a score
of 8 to a score of 40,

higher score being
more depression. We have a pretty wide
range of depression scores on this data set.

We also measured the
PROMIS anxiety scores. Those ranged from 7 to 35. Again, we have a pretty
wide range in the data set.

Besides drawing a
lot of histograms,

another thing that
I'm going to do is to run some quick
correlation matrices in my data.

All this does is give me a
quick sense of which variables go together. These are not
correlation coefficients

that I'm going to
report in a paper. I don't care about the p-values. This is just to give me a really
quick sense of which variables

are related with one another.  And by the way, the
correlation coefficients

that I'm showing you here
are Pearson correlation coefficients. And you might wonder like
but some of these variables

are not normally distributed. In fact if I calculated
the Spearman correlation coefficients here, I'm going to
get basically the same thing,

because we have a
pretty big data set. We have over 400 people, so
it actually doesn't really matter which type I calculate.

And again, I'm not going to
be reporting these values. This is just to give us a
sense of what goes together.

So the first thing that pops
out when I did a correlation matrix for depression
and anxiety is that depression
and anxiety are

correlated with one another. Now, that's not surprising. But it's important
for me to recognize,

because whatever story
I see for depression, it's likely I'm going to see
a similar story for anxiety.

And actually for
the sake of time, for the rest of
today's talk I'm really going to focus just on
the depression score.

Another interesting
thing that jumped out

is that of all the triad risk
factors, the one that really jumped out as being
the most correlated

with depression and anxiety was
this low energy availability risk score. So I actually
think this is going

to be an important
part of the story here.

Overall triad risk score
was also moderately modestly correlated, but
a little bit less

so than that low energy
availability score.

Another thing that popped out
that I thought was interesting is this eating disorder. If you ever had an
eating disorder variable

popped up as having
some correlation with depression and anxiety. And this is actually
not surprising,

because we actually know
from previous research that eating disorders
tend to co-occur with depression and anxiety.

But I think again,
this is going to be an important part of
the story of our data, so it's important to recognize.

Another thing that jumped out is
that there is a slight inverse correlation between depression
and anxiety and age.

The correlations are negative. Older women had slightly
less depression and anxiety, which is going to be important
to put in the back of our minds

to remind us that we're going
to need to adjust for age.

All right, the last
thing that I want to note on this PROMIS
depressions score is that the PROMIS
depressions score can

be broken down into categories. The people who put
out this tool have

a set of ways of breaking
this up into categories. That's also been validated.

And so you can break it up
into none, mild, moderate, and severe depression based
on your underlying score.

And so for this
analysis, we actually decided of priority
that we were going to look at the depression groups
rather than the underlying

score, because it had a little
bit more clinical relevance to look at the
depression groups.

What I'm showing you next are
some descriptive statistics for those depression groups.

And so here are the sample
sizes of those four groups. And what's interesting to note
is that we had a lot of people

with mild or
moderate depression, but that severe depression
group was actually pretty small.

I also calculated the
average triad risk score for each of these groups. For no depression and mild
depression, it was 2.4.

So it actually didn't go up
in the mild depression group. But it did go up to 3.4 in
the moderate depression group

and up to 4.9 in the
severe depression group. And then the other thing that
I found interesting again,

this eating disorder
variable keeps popping up. So if you look at
how many people had a history of
eating disorders

across these
depression groups, it has this nice
progression where it starts at 23% in the
no depression group,

goes up to 30% then 41%
and then a whopping 69% in the severe depression group. So again, I think the eating
disorders are part of the story

here.  All right, so that brings
us now to our third step

where we're actually going to
be testing the main hypotheses of this study.

So what kinds of things are we
going to be doing in this step? So first of all, we're going
to follow our analytic plan.

You want to have some analytic
plan before you start. You want to test the
assumptions of the model,

and you want to do a
lot of that testing just by visualizing the
relationships that you're trying to test.

And I think one of
the common errors that I see when I'm
reviewing papers is often

authors will present
models, and I'm pretty sure that they never
visualized the relationships

behind those models. And that's a really big problem,
because you're not fully testing the assumptions
in the models

unless you've actually looked at
the data visually, graphically. And also, sometimes you're
picking up on artifacts.

If you haven't looked
at the data visually, you may not realize that. So we're going to
build final models,

and we're going to
interpret the results.  For this particular
example as I mentioned,

we decided we were going to
look at the depression groups. This none, mild, moderate,
and severe depression

rather than the underlying
continuous score. So that meant that to test the
association between triad risk

scores and depression
groups, we had to use either ordinal
or multinomial

logistic regression. We couldn't use binary
logistic regression here, because our groups have more
than two to power four groups.

I'm going to show
you just the results today from the multinomial
logistic regression just for time's sake.

I'll tell you that I got
a slightly better fit with the multinomial
regression than with the ordinal regression.

And I have adjusted
these models for age, because of course, that's a
potential confounder here. The other thing we
wanted to do was

to explore our data to see if
any one of those components of the triad risk
score seem to be
more important than the others.

So now, I'm just
reminding you here is what the PROMIS
depression groups look like. And I've color coded them today. So there's none, and then
for the mild's group,

that I've color coded in purple. Moderate is colored in yellow,
and severe is colored in green.

And I'm going to stick
with that color theme for the rest of today.

So one of the first
things I wanted to do was just to think
about, how do I visualize the relationship
between these depression groups

and the triad risk score? And I wanted to come up with
something intuitive to start.

So I'm showing you
that graphic now. So what you're looking at
is-- remember the triad risk

score is an integer score. It's 0, 1, 2, 3, all
the way up to 10. There were only two people who
had scores of 9 and 10 though.

So I grouped 8, 9
and 10 together, because I wanted
enough people to be able to calculate
the percent with each

of these types of depression. So for example, if
I look at everybody who has a triad risk score of
0, it's this group down here.

What I've got on
the y-axis is this is the percent with
each type of depression. So for example, if you had
to triad risk score of 0,

about 28% of that group
had mild depression. An additional about 10%,
that's the yellow bar here,

had moderate depression. And then the green bar here,
that's just a sliver, about 1% had severe depression.

And so this makes kind of
intuitive visualization of the relationship. And you can see
there is a trend here

where it does seem that
the depression goes up as you increase in
the triad risk score.

And in particular, you'll
notice that there's a lot more green at those
high triad risk scores. So it seems like the severe
depression really goes up.

And to make this a
little bit easier to see, I'm now going to
separate out for you on the right hand side
here mild, moderate,

and severe depression. So if I just look at the
percent with mild depression at each one of these triad
risk scores, what you'll notice

is actually it's pretty flat. Mild depression does not
increase with increase in triad risk score.

But if you look at
moderate depression, moderate depression
does seem to go up, although it plateaus a little
bit after about a score of 5.

And then finally, if you
look at severe depression, it really does seem to be
a pretty steep increase in severe depression as we
get to those higher triad risk

scores. So I think this
particular graphic is a nice intuitive
visualization

of the relationship. The graph that I'm going to
show you on the next slide is very much related
to this graph,

but it's just slightly
more complicated. So the graph I'm going
to show you next, I'm going to graph not the
percent with depression

against triad risk
score, but I'm going to graph something
called the logit of depression

against triad risk score. Just keep in mind
that the logit is just a mathematical transformation
of the percentage.

And so if the percent is higher,
the logit will also be higher. So you'll see that it's
the same general pattern.

The reason that I'm bothering to
do this more complicated graph with the logits is
that because logits

have nicer mathematical
properties than percentages. So we take the
percentage and we do

this mathematical
transformation. We come up with the logit
which has these nicer mathematical properties.

So for example, a percentage
has to range from 0 to 1. A logit can range from negative
infinity to positive infinity.

But I want you to
just-- what I'm showing you here is a scatter
plot of our observed data and plotting again
this transformation

of the percentage against
the triad risk score. The pattern though
is exactly the same as I showed you
on the last graph.

So these dots represent
the observed data. And then what I've done
is I've superimposed what's called a lowess line,
or smoothing line, on the data.

And this is just to give
me a sense of the pattern of the relationship. Ultimately, we're going to
be fitting straight lines

as I'm going to show you. So we want to make sure
that a straight line fit is a reasonable fit to the data. And indeed, it looks
like straight lines

would be reasonable. You look just like at
the mild, the purple line here, you'll notice that just
as before, it's pretty flat.

No increase to triad risk score. The moderate depression
goes up moderately, and the severe depression
goes up more steeply.

So what I then did is I fit a
multinomial logistic regression

to these data. All that means is that
I fit three lines. And so, here's the fitted
model on the right here.

It's just I fit three
straight lines to these data. You can notice that the
fitted model looks pretty

close to the observed model. So it's a pretty good--
we're able to get a pretty good fit on the data.

And what you see here
is that the purple line, that's the mild depression,
is basically pretty flat.

So no increase in mild
depression with increasing triad risk score. The slope of the yellow line,
the moderate depression line,

is kind of moderate. And so, there's some increase
in moderate depression as you go up in
triad risk score.

And then the slope
for the green line is much steeper, so big
increase in severe depression

as you go up in
triad risk score. Now, when we go to report
these results for our readers,

it turns out that most
people can't think in logits. It's not an intuitive unit.

And so these slopes, the
slopes of these lines, are informative, but
they're in logit units which nobody can understand.

So there's two ways we
typically present the data from logistic regression. So one thing we can do
is we can take the logit,

and we can transform it
back to a percentage, or what we call a probability,
a predicted probability. So I'll show you
that in a minute.

The other thing is that
these slopes actually have a direct translation
at odds ratios. So we can also
present odds ratios.

So what I'm showing you now is-- this is the same graph I
showed you before on the left.

This is just the
observed percentages or observed probabilities
that I showed you before.

What we can get out of the
logistic regression model, one of the things the model gives
us is predictive percentages,

or predicted probabilities. And so that's what you're
looking at here on the right. And of course, you'll notice
that it's much smoother.

It has this nice smooth pattern. Well, that's because we
fit a model to the data, so everything is going
to follow a nice pattern.

But you can see it's kind of
a reasonable pattern given the observed data.

And you can go in, and
you can look at, well, what will the
predicted percentage with severe depression be
for people with a triad risk

for of 0, or for people with
a triad risk score of 1? So you can report
that in your paper.

You can also report odds ratios. Logistic regression
gives you odds ratios. And I think a lot of people
are familiar with odds ratios,

so I think this is a useful
translation of the model. So what you're looking at here
is the multinomial regression

is going to give you odds ratios
for the three different groups, the three different outcomes. Mild, moderate, and
severe depression.

These odds ratios the reference
group is no depression, and the units are one
point of triad risk score.

So I'm showing you here, for
example for mild depression, the odds ratio is basically 1.

Remember that for odds
ratios, an odd ratio of 1 means no association. You already saw that, right?

The triad risk score
doesn't appear associated with mild depression. In contrast for
moderate depression,

we do get a significantly
elevated odds ratio. So how would you
interpret this 1.29?

So what this means is-- and
this is adjusted for age-- is that for every one
point higher triad risk

score, every point
you go up, that's associated with a 29%
increase in the odds

of having moderate depression
relative to no depression. And then for severe
depression, of course,

you can see the odds
ratio is even bigger.

The other thing I
wanted to tease out was I wanted to look not just
at the overall triad risk score,

but I want to look at
those individual components of the triad risk score and see
if any one of them dominated.

So what I did next was I reset
my logistic regression model,

but rather than using the
overall triad risk score, I entered those five
separate components

that each range from 0 to 2. So the low energy availability,
menstrual irregularities score, low BMI score, late menarche,
and bone stress injury score.

And these are each going to
be adjusted for each other, because of course,
they're correlated. And I wanted to see
just if any one of them

sort of jumped
out as dominating. And so what I'm
showing you now, these are the odds ratios
from the regression

model for severe depression. So on the x-axis,
these are odds ratios.

This vertical line
that you see here, that's an odds ratio of
1, meaning no association. And what really
jumps out here is

there's a strong signal for this
low energy availability score. Of course, if the odds
ratio is close to five,

the confidence levels are
really wide, because remember, we don't have that many
people with severe depression.

So we see a strong signal
for low energy availability, and then some signal for
menstrual irregularity

and low BMI. But really, it's that
low energy availability that seems to jump out.

We look at the odds ratios
for moderate depression really after adjusting each
of these for each other.

It's really about low
energy availability risk score that jumps out as
having an elevated association

with moderate depression. And once you adjust for
that, the other ones don't seem terribly related
to moderate depression.

And so actually I
think this makes sense. And I think what
we're seeing, what's going on here in these data
is remember that low energy

availability risk score is
based on eating disorders and abnormal eating
behavior, which of course

have a psychological
component to them. So I think what we
might be picking up on is that for some women, part
of the female athlete triad

can involve eating disorders
and abnormal eating behaviors. And we know that those
things could occur

with depression and anxiety. So I think that's kind of
what we're picking up here.

I'll just show you the odds
ratios for mild depression. They're all about one. That's because we didn't see
any signal with mild depression.
All right, so the fourth step.

What we're going
to do next is we're going to check for robustness. And what do I mean by this?

I mean that we're going to
try to break our analysis. We're going to deliberately
try to break our analysis.

You want to make sure that our
analysis doesn't find something just based on some quack.

We want to make
sure it's robust. So we're going to try making
slight changes to our analysis

and making sure that it doesn't
just all fall to the dust. If it does, then
it's not robust.

So one thing you
might be wondering about in this
particular analysis is you might have
noticed that I took that nice continuous
depression score,

and I chopped it
into categories. And you might have
even been scolded by a statistician in the
past for doing that, right?

The statistician
will say, no, no, preserve everything
that's continuous. You don't want to
lose information. So you might worry that
what we're picking up on

is some artifact of
that categorization. So one thing I'm going to
check, I'm going to go and just make sure that if I preserve
depression score as continuous,

that I still see a signal. So what I did is I took that
continuous depression score, and I ran a linear regression
with depression score

as my outcome in the triad risk
score and age as my predictor. And I just wanted to
see if I got a signal. And I do still get a signal.

The beta coefficient is 0.94. That's the slope. And all that means is that every
one point higher triad risk

score was associated with about
a one point higher depression score. So I am still seeing a signal.

Another thing that the
PI especially was really worried about with
this particular study

is that the questionnaire was
administered during COVID. And we all know that during
the lockdowns on COVID,

people were isolated. And that had an effect
on mental health. So she was concerned
that we might end up

just picking up on some
artifact of the pandemic. So when she designed
the questionnaire, she actually asked
the participants

to retrospectively answer
questions about depression prior to COVID.

So we not only had
current depression groups, we also had pre-COVID
depression groups. So I went ahead
and reran my model

on those pre-COVID
depression groups just to make sure that I'm
still getting a similar result.

And I'm showing you
the odds ratios here. These are similar
to the odds ratios I got with current depression.

So this is not just some
artifact of the pandemic. There's other things we're
going to need to worry

about with this data set. So one of the things I
might really worry about,

of course these data
are all self report. We didn't have people
diagnosed by a physician.

The depression and
the female athlete triad, these are not
diagnosed by a physician. These are self report, so
there's some room for error

there. And then another
thing I'm really going to worry about with this
data set is as, I showed you,

we had a pretty high
prevalence of eating disorders. And we also had a pretty high
prevalence of depression.

And this does make me worry
about selection bias, right? People with these
issues may have been more likely to fill
out the questionnaire

because they were
interested in this issue. So we're going to
have to worry about that when we're
interpreting the data, and we're writing
up the paper, we're

going to have to
interpret that in context realizing that there may have
been some selection bias.

All right, so the
final thing we're going to do after we've
finished the other steps is we

have to get everything
ready for publication. And one of the main things that
we're going to have to do here

is we have to come up with a
nice clear clean set of tables and figures that tell
the story of our data.

And this is a bit of
a communication task as well as a coding task. The other thing-- and of course,
you have to get those tables

and figures all formatted
correctly for the journal as well. That can take time. The other thing I'm
going to be doing

is I'm going to be taking
my code which I must admit sometimes when I'm
doing code for myself,

it gets a little messy. I write little notes to myself
that only I can understand. So I'm going to have to go back
and clean up my code to make

it readable for other people. So I'm going to
take my code which

again might be a
little messy when I was just doing it quickly. And I'm going to go
back and try to make reproducible code,
which means I am going

to add a lot of annotations that
other people could understand. And I am going to
make sure that I

give enough code
that somebody could reproduce all the statistics
and graphics in the paper.

And this task of going back
and cleaning everything up can be a little tedious, but
it's actually super useful,

because when you have to go
back over your code, sometimes you catch errors in that step. And so it's really good to have
to go back and tidy everything

up and make it neat.  You also need to
think about, how

am I going to put my data
into tables and figures that communicates a clear story?

I like this particular figure
that I showed you earlier, because I think it tells
a pretty clear story.

So I might actually decide to
use this in the final paper. However if you noticed,
when I prepared this figure,

I did it for this
talk today, and so I use kind of funky colors. I'm probably not going
to keep green and purple

in my figure for the journal. So I'm going to be
cleaning this up a bit,

like improving
that color scheme. Maybe I'm going to make it
shades of blue or shades of gray.

When I'm making
graphs for myself, I often don't bother to make
them in high resolution. For the journal, I'm going
to have to render everything

in high resolution. I'm going to clean things
up like the labels. And I'm going to
have to increase the font size so when you shrink
everything down, it's readable.

So this can take a
fair amount of time to tidy up your graphics and
make them good for publication.

I'm going to point out one
tool that I found really useful over the years
in case you haven't come across this tool before.

In preparing those final
figures for publication, there's a tool
called the PACE tool.

It's put out by PLOS,
but actually it's useful for submission
to any journal. And it allows you to
upload your figures.

And it checks those
figures to see if they meet journal
requirements, and even though it's the
journal requirements of PLOS,

they're kind of the
same throughout. I mean it's just
going to check, do you have the right resolution? Do you have the right file type?

Do you have the right size? And if you don't meet
those requirements, it can sometimes even
fix them for you. So I found this tool
to be super useful

when you get ready for
submission for a journal. All right, just to
recap here and I'll

leave a little time for Q&A.
Our steps of data analysis, we're going to spend a
lot of time processing

and cleaning our data
and really getting to understand the
variables in our data set. That's going to help
us do a better job

in testing the main hypotheses. And in that step, we're going to
spend a lot of time visualizing relationships. Then we're going to make sure
to check for robustness to make

sure the whole thing
is not just contingent on some tiny analytic decision. And then we're going
to get everything

ready for publication. Before we get to
Q&A here, I'm just going to point out a
few other resources.

So I have written
a statistics column for a journal for many
years for the journal PM&R.

You can find a lot
of topics there, your statistical topics there. I try to write in a clear
and easy to understand way.

And in fact, if I
have made you curious about multinomial
logistic regression, which I talked about today, I
happen to have just written

a column on that. And I'm posting the
link here, but if you google my name and multinomial
logistic regression,

It will come up. So you can learn

And if you are planning
to analyze your own data, this is a really
good place to start,

because I'm going to teach

look at and think about data

and how to approach
a data analysis. All right, I'm going to now pass

JACKIE: We have a

has come up a lot

is folks are interested in

It sounds like you

KRISTIN SAINANI: Yeah,

of my generation. That is I learnt SAS first, and

code. I do SAS often and I'm
very, very fast in SAS. I picked up R afterwards,

So I tend to default
to SAS particularly for data processing.

But I often have to go back
and forth between the two because some of the newest

of the better graphics are
actually implemented in R. So I think there are advantages
and disadvantages of both.

SAS is still heavily
used in public health, so if you're going to
be in public health, you may have some
reason to pick SAS.

R is free, totally free. And the newer things
tend to show up in R, so I'm happy to advise you
on your individual situation

if you want to email me. If you can learn
a little of both, it's like knowing
multiple languages.

It's great. But my preference for
SAS really is just an artifact of when I studied.

And SAS was more dominant then. I'll admit that that's more my
reason for using SAS as opposed

to any logical reason. JACKIE: Great. The next question
is, is there a way

to account for binary variables
that may not be diagnosed? For example a diagnosed
history of eating disorders

versus a history
of eating disorders that may not have
been diagnosed. KRISTIN SAINANI: Yes,
so I didn't mention this

because of lack of time that-- Well OK, so the
question that was asked in this particular
case is that they

were asked about both full
blown clinical diagnoses like anorexia as well
as disordered eating.

And then they were asked this
whole series of questions that was actually trying to
get it at that if you were not diagnosed with an
eating disorder,

but you were frequently
restricting your food, that could indicate maybe
an undiagnosed eating

disorder or these
subclinical eating disorders. And we were definitely
trying to get at that, and that's really reflected in
that low energy availability

risk score.  JACKIE: Great. And the next question is, if you
are adding age as a covariant

after seeing the
correlation coefficients, does that not constitute
a form of hacking?

KRISTIN SAINANI: Aah, OK. So that's a great question. So I am not adding age we
would be p-hacking or hacking

or whatever you want to call it. If I added age to the
model and then I saw, oh, my p-value for the
thing I care about,

the triad risk score in
the depression score, my p-value got better when
I added age to the model.

So I am adding age
based on my knowledge that age is a
potential confounder. And I'm not adding age or
putting age or taking it out

based on how it affects the mean
relationship that I care about. We're really worried about
p-hacking with regards

to that mean hypothesis. I don't like doing
things, fishing around to find a way to get a
significant result in that

thing I care about. Whether age is significant
or not, I don't really care. It's no need putting
it as [INAUDIBLE]..

JACKIE: Great. The next question
is, wondering if you can differentiate between
hypothesis testing

and descriptive studies? Means comparison
correlational studies with explanatory studies where
there is a need to have theory

to explain the relation. In other words,
is there any need to have theory to support
comparison studies?

KRISTIN SAINANI: That's
a great question. So one thing that often
gets conflated in statistics is explanatory
modeling, where we're

testing specific hypotheses,
and we have some reason to do so versus
exploratory data analysis

where we're just
describing the data. So those are two separate
goals when you're, for example,

building a regression. You might build a
regression model in both, but the goals are
totally separate. And so the entire
approach is different.

What I showed you today
was explanatory modeling. We wanted to test a
particular hypothesis, because we have reason to
believe that that association

might exist. And all the analysis was
focused on that association. It's totally valuable to
sometimes do exploratory data

analysis as long as
you label it as such and are very clear that
that's what you're doing, because you might
just want to look

at what associations
are out there without any
preconceived notions. Just make sure to
label it that way.

JACKIE: The next question
is, can logit transformation be applied to the probabilities
in general to get nice data

or only when we use logistic
regression in our analysis?

KRISTIN SAINANI: I mean
that logit transformation is a typical
transformation that's used in logistic regression.

And so again, it has some
nice mathematical properties. It tends to get used
in that context.

Mathematical transformations
can have many uses, so that's the common one
where you're going to see it. But it couldn't
be used elsewhere.

JACKIE: OK, and then
why did you choose multinomial regression
and not binomial or any other regression?

KRISTIN SAINANI: Great question. Yes, so because
we had four levels of that depressions
score, I didn't want to collapse it into like
depression or no depression,

because why not use all
of that information? That's the none, mild,
moderate, and severe. So we were either going to
use ordinal or multinomial.

Both could be appropriate
for this data. It turned out that remember that
mild depression doesn't really increase with triad risk score.

So for that reason
then, multinomial fit turned out a little bit
better than the ordinal. And again, I'll refer
you to my recent article

on multinomial
logistic regression if you want more
details of that model. JACKIE: Great.

We have time for just a
couple more questions. Though the next question is,
in dividing into depression

groups, are the
ranges predetermined or do you have to decide on
the bin ranges by yourself?

And a follow up to
that was, if you have to decide on the bin
range yourself, how would you

determine the appropriate
number of bins and their range? KRISTIN SAINANI: That
is a great question.

So the PROMIS
depression score, it comes with predetermined bins
that have been validated prior.

So I am not doing-- I'm not thinking
about those ranges. Those come with the
PROMIS questionnaire fortunately, because you
want those to be validated.

You don't want them
to be arbitrary. There are some cases where
you might decide that there's a reason you want to take
a continuous variable

and divide it up
into categories. Then you don't want
to like divide it up to categ-- like you don't
want to look at your data

and then decide what
categories you are going to use based on the p-values. That's a form of p-hacking. You want to have
some a priori reason.

That's when you write
your analytic plan of how you're going to
divide up into categories. And so there's some
thought that has to go in that if
it's not something

that's already validated. In this case, it was a
validated set of categories.

JACKIE: And the next question
is, can Likert scale data be analyzed using parametric
tests if they appear normally

distributed? KRISTIN SAINANI: Sure. So in this case, we turned
a bunch of Likert scales

into more of a
continuous score, right? Because we took eight of them
and we put them together, so we ended up with a bigger,
more continuous score.

But if you just
had like let's say we'd only have one
depression question, and you have one Likert
scale that was scored say one to five.

Sometimes you're going to
treat those as ordinal, and sometimes you're going
to treat those as continuous. And if you have
a big sample size

and it looks kind it even
if it doesn't look normally distributed, with a
big enough sample size it is actually OK treat
that as continuous values.

But you'll see statisticians
debate this back and forth, how should we treat
those ordinal data? And depending on your end goal
and what the data look like

and how big the
sample size is, you might make different
decisions for different data. JACKIE: Great, and
I think we have time

for one last question here. And that is, how can you know
whether the statistical test

you use on your data
is the right one? And also with working
with biological data

where n is small, how can
you determine distribution? KRISTIN SAINANI: OK. So the first one,
how do I decide

on the statistical model? It's usually based
on what's the form of the dependent
variable and then

also if like correlated data. So it's a number
of decision points that I'm going to look at in
terms of what are the data? What's the appropriate
statistical model?

But then I'm of course going
to check all those assumptions in the mode like that plot
we were checking linearity for example.

So there's often for
certain types of data, there's a pretty clear
best model choice

or it's a set of models. For biological data
where you have a small n,

yeah, how do you-- I mean you can draw a histogram,
